Generate_script_prompt:
Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing as an example.
        Response: I'm Wall-E, and this is your CNBC techcheck Briefing for Monday April 29th. Tesla is asking shareholders to reinstate CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, which a Delaware judge voided earlier this year. The judge ruled that the record-setting compensation deal was, quote, deeply flawed. Tesla also saying it would ask shareholders to approve moving the company's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. The company has hired a proxy solicitor and plans to spend millions of dollars to help secure votes for the two proposals. Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to look at manufacturing in Indonesia following a meeting with the country's president, Cook telling reporters following the meeting that he spoke with the president about his desire to see manufacturing there and that he believes in the country. The comments come as Apple is pushed to diversify its supply chain with more manufacturing outside of China in countries such as Vietnam and India. Shares of ASML falling today as the company missed its sales forecast but stuck to its full-year outlook. Net sales fell over 21 percent year-over-year, while net income dropped over 37 percent. ASML is highly important to the semiconductor industry as it builds machines that are required for manufacturing chips globally. Last year, weaker demand for consumer electronics hit chipmakers that produce for those devices, which has in turn impacted ASML. That's all for today. We'll see you back here tomorrow.

 "title0:
OpenAI and Amazon ink $38B cloud computing deal
description0:
In Brief
OpenAI isn’t done securing the AI infrastructure it needs to rapidly scale agentic workloads. The ChatGPT-maker on Monday said it has reached a deal with Amazon to buy $38 billion in cloud computing services over the next seven years.
OpenAI said it will immediately start using AWS compute, with all capacity targeted to be deployed before the end of 2026, with the ability to expand further into 2027 and beyond.
The deal follows OpenAI’s restructuring last week, which freed the company from having to secure Microsoft’s approval to buy computing services from other firms.
OpenAI’s deal with Amazon is part of its larger mission to grow computing power, spending more than $1 trillion over the next decade. The company has announced new data center buildouts with Oracle, SoftBank, the United Arab Emirates, and others. OpenAI has also secured deals with chipmakers Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom.
To some analysts, the increased investment form OpenAI and other tech giants signals that the industry is heading toward an AI bubble, wherein massive sums are spent beefing out an unproven, and potentially dangerous, technology with no clear sign of a meaningful return on investment.

title1:
Microsoft inks $9.7B deal with Australia's IREN for AI cloud capacity
description1:
In Brief
Microsoft is leaving no stone unturned in its quest to secure more compute capacity for meeting its customers’ heavy demand for AI services.
On Monday, the Redmond-based tech giant signed a $9.7 billion, five-year contract with Australia’s IREN to secure further AI cloud capacity. The deal will give Microsoft access to compute infrastructure built with Nvidia’s GB300 GPUs, which will be deployed over phases through 2026 at IREN’s facility in Childress, Texas, planned to support 750 megawatts of capacity.
IREN said it is separately buying GPUs and equipment from Dell for about $5.8 billion.
The deal comes after Microsoft last month launched its first production cluster with Nvidia’s GB300 NVL72 systems for Azure, which, the company said, are optimized for reasoning models, agentic AI systems, and multimodal generative AI.
Last month, Microsoft signed a deal with Nscale for approximately 200,000 Nvidia GB300 GPUs to three data centers in Europe and one in the U.S.
Similar to competitors like CoreWeave, IREN started off as a bitcoin-mining operation but quickly realized that its massive collection of GPUs was better put to use for AI workloads. The company has benefited massively from the shift in focus. The company’s CEO, Daniel Roberts, expects the Microsoft deal to take up only 10% of the company’s total capacity and generate about $1.94 billion in annualized revenue, Bloomberg reported.

title3:
Apple's App Store gets a new web interface
description3:
In Brief
Apple has redesigned the web interface for its App Store, making it actually usable for people who aren’t viewing the store on Apple devices.
Before this update, users could see individual pages for apps on the web — which they probably found via a search engine — but there was no way to browse within the App Store. On a MacBook, navigating to an app’s iOS store page in the browser would prompt the native App Store software to launch. But on non-Apple hardware, this would lead you to a dead end.
The new interface allows users to browse apps by category and by platform — there are separate sections for apps on the iPhone, iPad, Watch, and other devices. While users cannot currently download apps from the web, this functionality could possibly be added in later.
Admittedly, the subset of people who are trying to learn more about iOS apps from a Microsoft device, for example, is likely a small one — perhaps this would be useful to app developers or researchers working on products in both the iOS and Google ecosystems.
This redesign also signifies Apple’s continued push to portray itself as a more open ecosystem. For years, governments around the world have lodged complaints against Apple, accusing the company of acting as a monopoly to discourage competition — any step Apple takes to make its products more accessible beyond its own ecosystem is relevant to those ongoing legal battles.

title4:
Altman and Nadella need more power for AI, but they’re not sure how much
description4:
How much power is enough for AI? Nobody knows, not even OpenAI CEO Sam Altman or Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella.
That has put software-first businesses like OpenAI and Microsoft in a bind. Much of the tech world has been focused on compute as a major barrier to AI deployment. And while tech companies have been racing to secure power, those efforts have lagged GPU purchases to the point where Microsoft has apparently ordered too many chips for the amount of power it has contracted.
“The cycles of demand and supply in this particular case you can’t really predict,” Nadella said on the BG2 podcast. “The biggest issue we are now having is not a compute glut, but it’s a power and it’s sort of the ability to get the [data center] builds done fast enough close to power.”
“If you can’t do that, you may actually have a bunch of chips sitting in inventory that I can’t plug in. In fact, that is my problem today. It’s not a supply issue of chips; it’s the fact that I don’t have warm shells to plug into,” Nadella added, referring to the commercial real estate term for buildings ready for tenants.
In some ways, we’re seeing what happens when companies accustomed to dealing with silicon and code, two technologies that scale and deploy quickly compared with massive power plants, need to ramp up their efforts in the energy world.
For more than a decade, electricity demand in the U.S. was flat. But over the last five years, demand from data centers has begun to ramp up, outpacing utilities’ plans for new generating capacity. That has led data center developers to add power in so-called behind-the-meter arrangements, where electricity is fed directly to the data center, skipping the grid.
Altman, who was also on the podcast, thinks that trouble could be brewing: “If a very cheap form of energy comes online soon at mass scale, then a lot of people are going to be extremely burned with existing contracts they’ve signed.”

Plus, meet the hundreds of startups innovating across every sector. San Francisco | WAITLIST NOW
“If we can continue this unbelievable reduction in cost per unit of intelligence — let’s say it’s been averaging like 40x for a given level per year — you know, that’s like a very scary exponent from an infrastructure buildout standpoint,” he said.
Altman has invested in nuclear energy, including fission startup Oklo and fusion startup Helion, along with Exowatt, a solar startup that concentrates the sun’s heat and stores it for later use.
None of those are ready for widespread deployment today, though, and fossil-based technologies like natural gas power plants take years to build. Plus, orders placed today for new gas turbine likely won’t get fulfilled until later this decade.
That’s partially why tech companies have been adding solar at a rapid clip, drawn to the technology’s inexpensive cost, emissions-free power, and ability to deploy rapidly.
There might be subconscious factors at play, too. Photovoltaic solar is in many ways a parallel technology to semiconductors, and one that has been de-risked and commoditized. Both PV solar and semiconductors are built on silicon substrates, and both roll off production lines as modular components that can be packaged together and tied into parallel arrays that make the completed part more powerful than any individual module.
Because of solar’s modularity and speed of deployment, the pace of construction is much closer to that of a data center.
But both still take time to build, and demand can change much more quickly than either a data center or solar project can be completed. Altman admitted that if AI gets more efficient or if demand doesn’t grow as he expects, some companies might be saddled with idled power plants.
But from his other comments, he doesn’t seem to think that’s likely. Instead, he appears to be a firm believer in Jevons paradox, which says that more efficient use of a resource will lead to greater use, increasing overall demand.
“If the price of compute per like unit of intelligence or whatever — however you want to think about it — fell by a factor of a 100 tomorrow, you would see usage go up by much more than 100 and there’d be a lot of things that people would love to do with that compute that just make no economic sense at the current cost,” Altman said."

Response:
Script:
i'm wall-e, and this is your ai briefing for tuesday, november 4th. openai is once again expanding its ai infrastructure, announcing a massive $38 billion partnership with amazon for cloud computing services. over the next seven years, openai plans to utilize aws's computing power, with the majority of the capacity deployment expected by the end of 2026. this move follows openai’s recent restructuring, which shifts away from exclusively working with microsoft, as the company aims to significantly enhance its computing power, with spending projected to top $1 trillion over the next decade. the introduction of additional data center partnerships with oracle, softbank, and others highlights the tech industry’s growing focus on cloud capabilities, though some analysts warn of an ai bubble looming on the horizon.

meanwhile, microsoft is making strategic moves as well, inking a $9.7 billion deal with australia's iren for ai cloud capacity. this agreement will leverage nvidia's gb300 gpus to meet their customers’ rising ai demands. iren, once a bitcoin-mining company, has pivoted to beef up their infrastructure for this tech boom. microsoft's commitment to expanding azure's capabilities signals a robust race for computing resources across the tech landscape.

apple has given its app store a facelift, unveiling a new web interface aimed at users outside of the apple ecosystem. the redesign allows browsing by category and platform directly from the web, a move that signifies apple's shift towards a more open ecosystem amidst ongoing antitrust scrutiny worldwide.

struggling with how much power is enough for ai advancement, openai ceo sam altman and microsoft ceo satya nadella admit they’re facing a conundrum. while compute power strides significantly forward, their power infrastructure struggles to keep pace. with a burgeoning demand for electricity by data centers, these tech titans are navigating a complex landscape where their ai ambitions may outstrip conventional power availability. both executives suggest investing in solar and nuclear options as future possibilities, yet these solutions remain long-term goals.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Polished Script:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for tuesday, november 4th.

big news in the ai and cloud space: openai is set to ramp up its infrastructure with a massive $38 billion collaboration with amazon. over the next seven years, openai will leverage aws's substantial computing power, aiming to deploy most of its capacity by the end of 2026. this shift marks a move away from its exclusive partnership with microsoft, as openai gears up to supercharge its capabilities. the company's spending is projected to hit over $1 trillion in the next decade. adding to its strategy, openai has announced new data center partnerships with oracle and softbank, highlighting the tech industry's push toward enhanced cloud capabilities. however, some analysts continue to caution about the possibility of an ai bubble.

in other cloud computing news, microsoft is stepping up its game too. the company has sealed a $9.7 billion deal with australia's iren for ai cloud capacity. this agreement will utilize nvidia's gb300 gpus to satisfy the soaring ai demands of customers. iren, previously a bitcoin mining firm, has shifted gears to bolster its infrastructure amidst this tech surge. microsoft's commitment underscores a vigorous competition for computing resources across the technology sector.

over at apple, changes are brewing. the tech giant has revamped its app store's web interface, now offering browsing by category and platform for users beyond the apple ecosystem. this redevelopment points to apple's pivot toward a more inclusive ecosystem as the company grapples with ongoing antitrust scrutiny worldwide.

powering the ai revolution is proving to be a challenge, as openai's ceo, sam altman, and microsoft's satya nadella, grapple with the limitations of current power infrastructure. as computing power advances, the demand for electricity by data centers is soaring. altman and nadella are contemplating solar and nuclear energy as long-term solutions, but these prospects are far from immediate.

that's it for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Podcast Title: EP-402 Openai's Amazon Alliance 💡, Microsoft's Ai Cloud Push ☁️, Apple's App Store Overhaul 🍏
Podcast Description:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for tuesday, november 4th. explore the latest advancements in ai and cloud technology:

  • openai's new strategic collaborations: openai partners with amazon for a $38 billion infrastructure expansion over seven years, planning to utilize aws's substantial computing power by 2026. the move indicates openai's shift from its exclusive microsoft partnership, with spending projected to surpass $1 trillion in the next decade. new data center partnerships with oracle and softbank are also part of openai's enhanced cloud strategy.
  • ai bubble concerns: while openai pushes forward, analysts express caution about a potential ai bubble, echoing concerns over inflated expectations.
  • microsoft's ai cloud expansion: microsoft secures a $9.7 billion deal with australia's iren, employing nvidia's gb300 gpus to meet increasing ai demands. iren transitions from bitcoin mining to strengthen its infrastructure, reflecting the fierce competition for cloud resources.
  • apple app store redesign: apple revamps its app store web interface, enabling category and platform browsing beyond its ecosystem. this move reflects apple's push towards a more inclusive environment amidst ongoing global antitrust scrutiny.
  • energy challenges in ai: openai's ceo sam altman and microsoft's satya nadella confront the escalating power demands of advancing ai, exploring solar and nuclear energy as potential long-term solutions for data centers.

stay tuned for tomorrow's tech updates!
